subject: Aerospace Engineering
statement_full_text:
Engineering shapes every part of our lives, from the small details on our phones to the aircraft that transport people across the world. Each detail is crafted to enhance many different products. My interest in design and creativity began through playing video games, where I expressed myself by designing personal projects. This initial interest led me to pursue analytics behind social media trends. For my HPQ, I explored why videos go viral and the data related. This experience taught me to look beyond numbers and identify underlying patterns within them. The key turning point was visiting KROHNE, a local engineering company. I was fascinated by how complex products work in unison through precise measurement. My passion for aerospace engineering began with Formula 1, where aerodynamics and precision drive performance. I was captivated by the speed and intensity of the sport and listening to Susie Wolff and Claire Williams on Netflix's 'Drive to Survive,' I realised that, despite being male-dominated, motorsport offered different careers that I could aspire to pursue. I enrolled in an aerospace course where we explored the flight mechanics of foam gliders and designed a more optimised solution that would counter current weaknesses. This involved iterative testing and constant criticism of aerodynamic performance. Webinars hosted by InvestIn highlighted the realities of a career in engineering. I was drawn to the dynamic, unpredictability, and the demand for both adaptability and resilience. Next, I gained hands-on experience at Judd Power, utilising SolidWorks, where I designed 3D models, including an engine cover that was integrated into their design. This experience cemented my passion for design and my love for the fast-paced field of motorsport and aeronautics.
Studying Product Design enhanced my interest in engineering and design, as it allowed me to develop skills, exploring CAD and CFD inspired me to do further research into their applications in engineering. I began watching Chain Bear on YouTube, discussing aerodynamics and taught me concepts, like downforce and vortex reduction. Managing the demands of my NEA coursework with three other subjects was a challenge, forcing me to develop my organisation and time management skills, ensuring I stayed on schedule and met personal deadlines. Pursuing Further Maths outside of school has been a challenge that has been pushed by my personal motivation. It has taught me the importance of self-directed study and of fully mastering a topic before moving on. In Physics and Maths Society at school, I presented complex topics such as the Dual-Axis Steering (DAS) system from the 2020 Mercedes F1 car, improving my confidence and communication of technical ideas. Beyond education, I took part in an online course run by TEDI. It was based on sustainable fashion, a topic that I had never considered for designing a product for, but found I really enjoy. This course challenged me to apply my design and reasoning skills in a new aspect of engineering and really pushed me out of my comfort zone.
Outside of education, I am a member of my town's football team, where I have developed in skill, communication, and trust. Volunteering with a female karting team allowed me to gain practical experience with kart mechanics, understanding of the different engine types used across different race series, and through analysing data with a racer and their mentor, I learned the importance of teamwork and clear communication needed in high-pressure environments. This was reinforced when I spent a day down in the Formula E paddock with Girls on Track, where we were shown different roles in motorsport and how we could get involved with different motorsports at a younger age. I completed an online course with JLR, the highlight being designing a custom car, and justifying my design choices. I attended a course in London, hosted by InvestIn, where we explored the many different engineering fields and different engineers spoke about careers, mentioning the benefits and flaws. I volunteered at a local primary school to explore these subjects in further education. I ran interactive sessions, showing pupils how to create non-Newtonian fluids. I took part in a work experience programme, run by STEMETTES, where I helped deliver an event to primary school pupils and supported the design of online activities for the future. These experiences fuelled my desire to inspire and educate the next generation of STEM pupils.

feedback_items.weak_passage: Engineering shapes every part of our lives, from the small details on our phones to the aircraft that transport people across the world.
feedback_items.your_feedback: This is fluff that doesn't tell you anything specific. It's not specific and tutors don't look at this and think 'wow, this person really understands engineering.' You need a little bit of an opening, but this doesn't actually demonstrate understanding.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Choose one opening and bring in a specific fact earlier, or mention a specific feature from video games that demonstrates engineering understanding.

feedback_items.weak_passage: My interest in design and creativity began through playing video games... This initial interest led me to pursue analytics behind social media trends.
feedback_items.your_feedback: This is like having two introductions. The logic doesn't follow well - you go from definition of engineering to interest in video games to suddenly social trends. This feels like a third intro and the connection isn't clear.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Choose one introduction approach and make the connections between topics more logical and clear.

feedback_items.weak_passage: For my HPQ, I explored why videos go viral and the data related.
feedback_items.your_feedback: You mean EPQ, not HPQ. 'The data related' is not clear - what do you mean? Could you say how you calculate engagement or the importance of specific figures? Be specific about what you actually did.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Clarify exactly what data you analyzed and what specific conclusions you reached. For example, explain the exact regressions you ran and the results.

feedback_items.weak_passage: This experience taught me to look beyond numbers and identify underlying patterns within them.
feedback_items.your_feedback: This whole bit could have been expanded into a few sentences to say exactly what you did, the data you collected, the exact regressions you ran, and the results. You're not giving enough information to actually know what you did.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Expand with: This is exactly what we did. This is the data collected. These are the exact regressions we ran, and this is the result.

feedback_items.weak_passage: visiting KROHNE, a local engineering company. I was fascinated by how complex products work in unison through precise measurement.
feedback_items.your_feedback: That's all you say about it - not a huge amount of detail coming through. What specifically fascinated you? What did you learn?
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Add specific details about what you observed and learned at KROHNE.

feedback_items.weak_passage: listening to Susie Wolff and Claire Williams on Netflix's 'Drive to Survive,' I realised that, despite being male-dominated, motorsport offered different careers
feedback_items.your_feedback: This conclusion isn't the world's greatest. It would be better to talk about the actual engineering in an academic sense rather than the diversity aspect.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Focus on the engineering concepts and technical aspects rather than the diversity angle.

feedback_items.weak_passage: we explored the flight mechanics of foam gliders and designed a more optimised solution that would counter current weaknesses.
feedback_items.your_feedback: This stuff is interesting but it would be better if you could actually say what the more optimised solution is, because you just say you were looking at it but don't conclude what you found.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Explain what the optimised solution actually was and what specific weaknesses it addressed.

feedback_items.weak_passage: This experience cemented my passion for design and my love for the fast-paced field of motorsport and aeronautics.
feedback_items.your_feedback: This is filler language, same as an earlier sentence. Almost half your statement is just kind of filler language, which is a bit of a shame. Instead, explain how you made the engine cover - add two sentences explaining exactly what you did.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Replace this conclusion with specific technical details about how you designed the engine cover in SolidWorks. Show you're able to do that work already by proving it.

feedback_items.weak_passage: exploring CAD and CFD inspired me to do further research into their applications in engineering.
feedback_items.your_feedback: This part is really interesting but would be good to add another sentence saying specifically what you did with CAD and CFD.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Explain one specific application or project where you used CAD/CFD and what you learned.

feedback_items.weak_passage: I began watching Chain Bear on YouTube, discussing aerodynamics and taught me concepts, like downforce and vortex reduction.
feedback_items.your_feedback: This is just name dropping. If you could explain one particular outcome or experiment or something, that would be better.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Explain a specific concept you learned and how you applied or explored it further.

feedback_items.weak_passage: In Physics and Maths Society at school, I presented complex topics such as the Dual-Axis Steering (DAS) system from the 2020 Mercedes F1 car
feedback_items.your_feedback: What do you mean by 'presented it'? This needs one sentence of development. You should explain exactly how you presented it and what you found about the DAS system. Tutors want to know not just that you did it, but what you took from it.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Add one sentence explaining how you presented it and what specific understanding you gained about the DAS system. This is what sets you apart from everyone else who could say they presented something.

feedback_items.weak_passage: improving my confidence and communication of technical ideas.
feedback_items.your_feedback: The number of times you're mentioning this soft skills stuff is getting repetitive. You've said similar things multiple times.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Remove or significantly reduce mentions of general skills like confidence and communication.

feedback_items.weak_passage: I took part in an online course run by TEDI. It was based on sustainable fashion, a topic that I had never considered for designing a product for.
feedback_items.your_feedback: Are you going to tell me what the product is? It would be great just to know what you actually did. There's nothing specific here.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Describe the specific product you designed and what made it interesting or challenging.

feedback_items.weak_passage: This course challenged me to apply my design and reasoning skills in a new aspect of engineering and really pushed me out of my comfort zone.
feedback_items.your_feedback: This is another filler sentence. You're repeating this type of conclusion too often and not finding much value in it because it's so generic.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Remove this generic conclusion or replace with specific technical learning.

feedback_items.weak_passage: in the Formula E paddock with Girls on Track, where we were shown different roles in motorsport and how we could get involved
feedback_items.your_feedback: This sounds like you're advertising the programme rather than showing what you learned. How does this endear you to a tutor? It reads like 'oh cool, I should send my kids to that' but doesn't make them think 'this person is gonna be a great student.'
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Bring in something specific you learned, like 'because we did this, I learned that this is what I want to do' - make it about your learning, not the programme.

feedback_items.weak_passage: I completed an online course with JLR... I attended a course in London, hosted by InvestIn... I volunteered at a local primary school... I took part in a work experience programme
feedback_items.your_feedback: All of this extracurricular stuff is take it or leave it - none of this is really the make or break thing. Your writing is not very concise. You could reduce this by 50% while keeping the same meaning quite easily.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Cut this section down by 50% using more concise language. This will free up space to add sentences where technical detail is needed earlier in the statement.

feedback_items.your_feedback: Overall assessment: There's nothing that's a red flag, so you could leave it as is. But if you want to take it to the next level from an average statement to a 7 or 8, you need to add more specific detail and examples throughout. The structure and sections are fine, but almost half the statement is filler language.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Read appropriate SKILL.md files before starting work. Add specific technical details, examples, and conclusions throughout. Cut filler language by 50% to make room for substantive content. Focus on showing your understanding through specific examples rather than generic statements.
feedback_items.strong_passage: Pursuing Further Maths outside of school has been a challenge that has been pushed by my personal motivation. It has taught me the importance of self-directed study and of fully mastering a topic before moving on.
feedback_items.why_strong: This is good - shows genuine personal motivation and self-directed learning.

subject: Educational Psychology
statement_full_text:
Why do you want to study this course or subject?

I read an article exploring how student mental health is under increasing strain now more than ever due to social disruptions including the pandemic, economic pressures and even natural disasters. In the EU, 40% of students in higher education report troubles with their mental health or wellbeing. This growing issue gives the opportunity for psychological research to excel and find appropriate approaches to support these students. In another survey, psychological researchers identified 'federated learning' using AI as a suitable method as it can observe mental health data without breaching confidentiality. This matter made me appreciate the important role of psychological research in education and how it can supply ethical approaches to a grave issue like mental health. Listening to podcasts by the British Psychological Society expanded my understanding on the variety of psychological research and how this can be applied to almost anything from superstition to grief. The magnitude of the role that psychology plays in daily life intrigues me, especially how it can be utilised in education to improve the lives of students. For example, according to the EEF, psychological findings show that using metacognitive and self-regulation strategies provide an extra eight months of progress compared to the usual over a year.

How have your qualifications and studies helped you to prepare for this course or subject?

My A-Level Spanish course has widened my outlook on how linguistic and cultural influences shape communication and behaviour, linking closely to social psychology. Learning and using this second language have also made me more curious about cognitive psychology and how the brain processes and stores language. My A-level history course has sharpened my ability to critically evaluate sources and assess bias, essential skills in psychology when interpreting case studies or research findings. My A-Level maths course has enabled me to develop problem solving techniques which will enhance my ability to tackle psychological questions logically as well as to assess the validity of different hypotheses. In addition to this, A-Level maths will ensure that I have the skills to thrive with statistics and data interpretation, important components of a psychology course.

What else have you done to prepare outside of education, and why are these experiences useful?

An 'introduction to psychology' MOOC from Yale had me particularly interested in clinical, developmental and educational psychology. Reading 'The Man Who Mistook His Wife for a Hat' by Oliver Sacks, a clinical psychologist, made me understand how personal accounts can highlight complex neurological and developmental disorders. I then completed a MOOC called 'Understanding child development: from synapse to society' by Utrecht University which taught me how different themes such as social, cognitive and emotional psychology come together to produce a clearer understanding of development. After completing the MOOC 'Childhood adversity: the impact of childhood maltreatment on mental health' by UCL, I began to understand the correlation between traumatic events early in life with development and that this increases the chances of mental health issues in later life. The course gave me an insightful view from a clinician, neuroscientist and an educator which taught me that this and many other current psychological issues are applicable to a variety of fields. I followed up my interest from these courses with my own practical work experience where I applied psychological theory in educational contexts in both a nursery for a year and then with a SENCO in a primary school where I learnt how teaching methods adapt to children with a variety of disorders. I worked closely with a child who had experienced trauma, and I was able to see how this affected him as a year 5 student with a mental age of a year 2 who resented any loss of routine and could not cope without assistance. I also had a meeting with an educational psychologist which gave me an opportunity to learn about their role and develop my interest in this area.

feedback_items.weak_passage: I read an article exploring how student mental health is under increasing strain
feedback_items.your_feedback: Can you name the article? You need to name it. When using sources like this, you have to bring in the actual title and author in case they want to check it themselves.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Include the full article title and author name.

feedback_items.weak_passage: In the EU, 40% of students in higher education report troubles with their mental health or wellbeing.
feedback_items.your_feedback: Who is that report by? When using statistics like this, you need to cite the actual source.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Include the source of this statistic with author/organization and publication details.

feedback_items.weak_passage: 'federated learning'
feedback_items.your_feedback: You've put federated learning in quotations but I'm not sure why. If you're including this new term, you should include a little subclause explaining what federated learning is according to you, because they will want to know that you understand these concepts and can work with them, not just putting them in quotes and hoping for the best.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Remove the quotation marks and add a brief explanation of what federated learning is to demonstrate your understanding.

feedback_items.weak_passage: This matter made me appreciate the important role of psychological research in education and how it can supply ethical approaches to a grave issue like mental health.
feedback_items.your_feedback: This is a very wordy sentence. Just say 'I appreciate the role psychological research plays in education.' Think about how you can reduce words - this helps you identify what was actually useful content versus fluff and filler.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Condense to: 'I appreciate the role psychological research plays in education.'

feedback_items.weak_passage: how it can supply ethical approaches to grave issues like mental health
feedback_items.your_feedback: I would prefer you just told me specifically what is the role of psychological research in education. You haven't actually explicitly said what the role is and you haven't said what the ethical approaches are. You're just reading like a summary where I'm supposed to agree with you and know what you're talking about.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Explicitly state what the role of psychological research in education is and what specific ethical approaches you're referring to.

feedback_items.weak_passage: how this can be applied to almost anything from superstition to grief
feedback_items.your_feedback: I would rather you told me how is it applied to superstition and grief. You're being very vague and general saying it can be applied to anything broadly. Are you going to tell me what?
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Provide specific examples of how psychological research applies to superstition or grief, rather than just listing topics.

feedback_items.weak_passage: The magnitude of the role that psychology plays in daily life intrigues me
feedback_items.your_feedback: You're not going to tell me what the magnitude is. Again, you're just repeating that it can be utilised in education to improve lives with no specific example.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Explain what you mean by 'magnitude' with concrete examples.

feedback_items.weak_passage: For example, according to the EEF, psychological findings show that using metacognitive and self-regulation strategies provide an extra 8 months of progress
feedback_items.your_feedback: This comes out of nowhere. This could be quite interesting to develop - you could say this is what they looked at, this is what we mean by 8 months of progress, but there's no context here. In isolation this doesn't make sense. You need a couple of sentences surrounding this to introduce the study, explain what happened, and explain what's going on now.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Add context before this statistic: introduce the study, explain the methodology, and develop what the '8 months of progress' actually means.

feedback_items.weak_passage: My A-Level Spanish course has widened my outlook on how linguistic and cultural influences shape communication and behaviour, linking closely to social psychology. Learning and using this second language have also made me more curious about cognitive psychology and how the brain processes and stores language. My A-level history course has sharpened my ability to critically evaluate sources and assess bias, essential skills in psychology when interpreting case studies or research findings. My A-Level maths course has enabled me to develop problem solving techniques which will enhance my ability to tackle psychological questions logically as well as to assess the validity of different hypotheses. In addition to this, A-Level maths will ensure that I have the skills to thrive with statistics and data interpretation, important components of a psychology course.
feedback_items.your_feedback: This entire paragraph is unusable. You shouldn't be writing about A Level in the first place - it doesn't matter. Your qualifications are supposed to be a leapboard to say 'I used this as a basis to approach a MOOC, and in the MOOC I learned this and this and this.' But you repeating what you learn in A Level in a broad summary sense is not helping anybody.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Delete this entire section and move some MOOCs from paragraph 3 to replace it. Focus on what you learned beyond A Level, not the A Level content itself.

feedback_items.weak_passage: An 'introduction to psychology' MOOC from Yale had me particularly interested in clinical, developmental and educational psychology.
feedback_items.your_feedback: Full stop after this? No, you can't do that. You need to say 'one particular concept we learned or studied was this. And I find this really interesting because it explains this. And I saw one of the studies that they ran was this, and this was the results. And I think this is super interesting, especially applied to modern day, because we see this in XYZ scenarios.'
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Expand each MOOC to 3-4 sentences: what specific concept you learned, why it's interesting, what studies or evidence supports it, and how it applies to real situations.

feedback_items.weak_passage: Reading 'The Man Who Mistook His Wife for a Hat' by Oliver Sacks, a clinical psychologist, made me understand how personal accounts can highlight complex neurological and developmental disorders.
feedback_items.your_feedback: You could develop this by saying 'often we can mistake one disorder such as X for another one, Y. And this is because clinical psychologists look at personal accounts, and then this one particular case, there was this case where this happened, and this could have been overcome by looking at it this way.'
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Give a specific example of a disorder from the book and explain how personal accounts revealed something that clinical assessment might miss.

feedback_items.weak_passage: I then completed a MOOC called 'Understanding child development: from synapse to society' by Utrecht University which taught me how different themes such as social, cognitive and emotional psychology come together
feedback_items.your_feedback: You've just listed MOOCs without developing anything. All of these should be 3-4 sentences developed out. You've got 4-5 MOOCs - move a couple up to replace the A Level section, cut some of the bottom bit, and make everything clearer.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: For each MOOC, explain: what specific concept you studied, what evidence or studies you encountered, and how it changed your understanding. Move some MOOCs to paragraph 2.

feedback_items.weak_passage: I applied psychological theory in educational contexts in both a nursery for a year and then with a SENCO in a primary school
feedback_items.your_feedback: What psychological theory? How? What did you do? You're saying you learned how teaching methods adapt to children with a variety of disorders - what disorders, how do you adapt them?
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Specify which psychological theories you applied, what specific disorders you encountered, and exactly how teaching methods were adapted.

feedback_items.weak_passage: I worked closely with a child who had experienced trauma, and I was able to see how this affected him as a year 5 student with a mental age of a year 2
feedback_items.your_feedback: You don't tell me what trauma. I'm always waiting for you to explain the detail. This is what all of you are doing - nobody's explaining anything.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: While being appropriately sensitive, explain what type of trauma and specifically how it manifested in the child's behavior and learning.

feedback_items.your_feedback: Overall: The first paragraph needs cleanup - develop points more, apply them, give specific examples. Quote those papers and articles. The second paragraph (A Level section) is your biggest problem and should be deleted entirely - replace it with MOOCs from paragraph 3. The third paragraph lists too many MOOCs without development - each needs 3-4 sentences explaining what you learned, not just that you took them.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: 1) Delete entire A Level paragraph. 2) Move 2-3 MOOCs to replace it. 3) Develop remaining MOOCs with specific concepts, studies, and applications (3-4 sentences each). 4) Add sources/citations to paragraph 1. 5) Add specific details to work experience section. 6) Reduce length slightly to free up space for development.

subject: Engineering
statement_full_text:
Why do you want to study this course or subject?
Growing up, I recall disassembling toys and household appliances to investigate how moving parts and electrical circuits worked daily. I found myself asking, 'How do things move on their own?" year by year, these thoughts continued to linger; this has led me to understand how I could use this conviction to develop systems which people use every day.
Throughout my academic journey, I have built my knowledge around various fields of engineering and how important this is in modern life. As expected, engineering is at the heart of how societies operate, from small elements of mechanical systems which power transportation networks to the electrical systems which keep the world connected. Therefore, my goal is simple: I want to develop my knowledge and understanding of how systems collaborate to create the technology we use on a day- to-day basis. This will help me address problems on a global scale.
How have your qualifications and studies helped you prepare for this course or subject?
My current studies in Mathematics and Physics have allowed me to build upon my ability to use abstract notions in tangible, practical contexts. For example, within the mechanics module of the course, I was exposed to kinematics; here, I used calculations to determine forces and acceleration with precision for a block sliding down an inclined surface. A major obstacle I came across was calculating the acceleration by balancing the forces of gravity and friction. I used Newton's principles and algebra to work this out. Today, I am aware of the importance of math modelling when it comes to the world of engineering.
To develop my knowledge further, I took the initiative and availed myself of 'To Engineer is Human'. Here, I was exposed to how engineering involves a multitude of theoretical modules, which are evaluated against reality. From my understanding, design failures can lead to advancements within the field, and as an aspiring Engineer, I am constantly striving to enhance different models which are of my calibre. This is important in maintaining an equilibrium between gravity and friction, step by step, to discover acceleration.
What else have you done to prepare outside of education, and why are these experiences useful?
My professional experiences at the Orsted virtual program have given me insight into how theory works in the real world. Here, I took part in a multitude of activities where innovation came together to provide effective and long-lasting solutions. From my understanding, the concept of engineering is all about having a long-lasting effect, as I have gone through a multitude of video courses and case studies; this has walked me through the process of managing large-scale renewable projects. This has given me the opportunity to adopt an 'engineering mindset', as I became more disciplined and better at solving problems.
Additionally, I exposed myself to the Siemens virtual work experience, where I developed my knowledge on how sustainability and design choices work together simultaneously in big projects. I observed the various engineers weigh the pros and cons of several designs and express their different concepts of innovation to each other. This was a moment of realisation for me: communication is at the forefront of engineering, a core skill I have built during my experiences.
This led me to take part in an engineering project, where I was responsible for solving a challenge. One of the parts I struggled with the most included coming up with a construction which could hold up weight without using too much material. Therefore, to solve the problem, I used the foundation I had already built in Engineering over my academic journey and applied it directly to this project. My approach was simple: I assessed the forces which were operating on the system. I applied physics and algebra to figure out where the stress would lead to the system breaking. From this, I investigated several design alternatives which tested how changes in shape changed both the stability and efficiency. Today, I understand how failures are chances to change, as each unsuccessful model taught me how to make the next system better.

feedback_items.weak_passage: Growing up, I recall disassembling toys and household appliances to investigate how moving parts and electrical circuits worked daily.
feedback_items.your_feedback: You don't even give an example of a toy or appliance. I have to presume it could be a kettle, microwave - these are all wildly different. If I were to take apart a microwave or kettle, I don't know what I would learn. I don't even know what toys you referred to - could be a Scooby-Doo for all I know. You haven't really said anything.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Include a specific example: 'I had an experience with this appliance that I took apart and it was really fun and I found out XYZ scientific processes. So I looked at a textbook and then a lecture and learned that this is how it actually works, and I applied it to my work.'

feedback_items.weak_passage: I found myself asking, 'How do things move on their own?' year by year, these thoughts continued to linger; this has led me to understand how I could use this conviction to develop systems which people use every day.
feedback_items.your_feedback: You don't give me the answer about how things move. You just thought about it. And you're definitely not going to tell me what systems you're talking about or what people are using every day. Is it a car, is it a bottle of milk? Who knows? We will never know. This whole first paragraph - I haven't learned a single thing about you.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Actually answer the question you posed and give specific examples of systems you want to develop.

feedback_items.weak_passage: As expected, engineering is at the heart of how societies operate, from small elements of mechanical systems which power transportation networks to the electrical systems which keep the world connected.
feedback_items.your_feedback: You say 'as expected' as if you have proved it in the last sentence, as if you've given me all the evidence and conclusively shown engineering is at the heart of how societies operate. Then you give vagueness about small elements and transportation systems. You might as well just list oranges, apples and grapes - that's how much meaning you're giving me.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Remove the generic statements and provide specific examples with technical detail.

feedback_items.weak_passage: my goal is simple: I want to develop my knowledge and understanding of how systems work... to create the technology... on a day to day basis... address problems on a global scale
feedback_items.your_feedback: What systems? What technology? What day to day basis? What problems on a global scale? You could put these same two paragraphs in anybody's personal statement, regardless of what they're studying, as long as it's STEM, and it would still make sense. It's nothing unique, no evidence, nothing about how you went through your journey.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Be specific about which systems, which technologies, which problems. Make it unique to your experience and understanding.

feedback_items.weak_passage: within the mechanics module of the course, I was exposed to kinematics; here, I used calculations to determine forces and acceleration with precision for a block sliding down an inclined surface
feedback_items.your_feedback: This is A Level Maths content. Because you don't have Further Maths and you're applying to Oxbridge, you need MORE maths content and higher level stuff to show you're capable of higher level mathematics. It's fine to use this to say you were introduced to kinematics, but you need higher level stuff here.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Start with A Level but extend upward: go to an undergrad first year textbook, find kinematics topics, look at what problems come up, search for studies using those techniques, and write about that higher level application.

feedback_items.weak_passage: To develop my knowledge further, I took the initiative and availed myself of 'To Engineer is Human'.
feedback_items.your_feedback: This is the first time you actually introduce a source, which is crazy because we're already halfway through. Also, you don't quote the author.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Include the author's name when citing this book, and introduce sources much earlier in the statement.

feedback_items.weak_passage: engineering involves a multitude of theoretical modules, which are evaluated against reality
feedback_items.your_feedback: Could anybody have written that sentence and it made sense for their subject? If yes, then it's too generic.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Make it specific to engineering with concrete examples.

feedback_items.weak_passage: From my understanding, design failures can lead to advancements within the field, and as an aspiring engineer, I am constantly striving to enhance different models which are of my calibre.
feedback_items.your_feedback: From your understanding - but where did this understanding come from? What is a design failure? What advancements? What models? How to enhance them? What is your calibre? You don't have to capitalise Engineer either.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Provide specific examples of design failures from the book, what advancements resulted, and which models you're working to enhance.

feedback_items.weak_passage: My professional experiences at the Orsted virtual program have given me insight into how theory works in the real world.
feedback_items.your_feedback: What does that mean? I wouldn't call it professional experience, just call it experiences. Then tell me what you actually did - tell me a project, tell me specific details.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Remove 'professional' and describe a specific project or activity from the program with technical details.

feedback_items.weak_passage: From my understanding, the concept of engineering is all about having a long-lasting effect
feedback_items.your_feedback: Why? When? Where did that come from? How am I supposed to believe that? Where did you get that from? What video courses? What case studies? What large scale renewable products?
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Provide evidence and specific examples for this claim. Name the courses and case studies.

feedback_items.weak_passage: the Siemens virtual work experience, where I developed my knowledge on how sustainability and design choices work together simultaneously in big projects
feedback_items.your_feedback: This sounds really interesting - just tell me what you actually did. Tell me what the big project was. Tell me what sustainability and design projects mean, what part they have to play.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Describe the specific project, the sustainability challenges, and the design trade-offs you observed.

feedback_items.weak_passage: This led me to take part in an engineering project, where I was responsible for solving a challenge. One of the parts I struggled with the most included coming up with a construction which could hold up weight without using too much material.
feedback_items.your_feedback: What is the engineering project? Tell me what it was. You're talking very vaguely about it. Instead of telling me that you used physics and maths, just say: we started off by getting resources from here, we used those resources to build this thing, we consulted this book which told us M-shaped bridges versus T-shaped bridges are best. This is your area of interest - you need more detail.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Describe the specific project (bridge competition? structural challenge?), the constraints, the materials, the specific design you chose, and why that design was optimal. Reference specific engineering principles or texts.

feedback_items.your_feedback: The structure and sections are lovely - you've got the intro, course content, experiences. But you need to add specific detail. I could copy paste this personal statement to anybody and it wouldn't contradict their life story. That's the problem. The kids who do really well add the specific detail. Because you don't have Further Maths for Oxbridge, you especially need more high-level maths content.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Don't change the storyline or sections - just add specific detail throughout. Include: specific appliances/toys you took apart and what you learned, specific systems/technologies you're interested in, higher-level maths beyond A Level (use undergrad textbooks as a starting point), author names for books, specific projects from virtual experiences with technical details, and specific engineering project details (what you built, materials, design choices, principles applied). This will go from a 5 to an 8.

subject: Land Economy
statement_full_text:
Growing up in Hulme and Lagos showed me that distant places can echo similar challenges. In both, economic regeneration and development has been at the expense of the inner city, sustaining social division and urban deprivation. Witnessing these conditions led me to question how policy neglect shapes the individual experience of the built environment. Geography and Economics give me the opportunity to find the answer and explore how I can confront urban inequality to build more inclusive urban futures.
A UNIQ Summer School lecture introduced me to Ghanaian farming tenancy contracts. I was particularly interested in the 'abunu' system (where landlord and farmer share land and produce equally). Realising the potential for power asymmetry between landlord and farmer, I wanted to understand their relationship further. To this end, I read an article on tenurial relations in rural Ghana. Its argument that abunu inhibits land control and equality for farmers was valid. However, by ignoring the economic rationale for choosing the contracts, it failed to address why these arrangements persist. I resolved this by modelling hypothetical cost and revenue functions to compare outcomes in abunu and a fixed rent system. Abunu, though less profitable, mitigated the financial risk of failed harvests and labour shortages present in fixed rent agreements. This risk-averse response showed me how uncertainty influences choice, a theme I discussed in my commended entry to the Gerald O'Connell Essay Prize.
Caldeira's 'City of Walls' exposed me to how urban geography can reveal power imbalances embedded into cities. The 'condomínios fechados', with their high walls and gated upper-class communities, were particularly striking when set against the expansion of informal 'favela' settlements. The contrast of security and affluence versus poor state control and infrastructure presented a spatially and socially fragmented city. This challenged me to see space not as neutral, but a device for socio-economic and political control. A Guardian article on Brazilian social housing highlighted the ineffective policy response of the government. I mostly agreed with the critique that housing was distant from economic activity and construction firms prioritised profitable margins over quality. Yet, the article ignored the benefits of state-backed mortgage and credit provision to São Paulo's poorest families, enabling property ownership. This tension showed me how policy can promote economic inclusion and entrench inequality. I am excited to grapple with tensions in policy more broadly in future study.
Reading Ben Wilson's 'Urban Jungle' made me question nature's place in the contemporary city. I explored his central argument, that rewilding cities reflects our innate affinity to nature, further through a research project into biophilic design in Singapore. My research, which I entered to the St John's College Poster Competition, involved analysing data from health journal articles to understand the effects of natural spaces like Gardens by the Bay on mental health. In finding reductions in depression and anxiety risk, the benefits of greening were clear. Yet, there were also limitations. Extensive capital investment and coordination are needed to promote urban greening, making me question its feasibility in all urban contexts. These limitations became clearer in considering Lagos. I found the opportunity cost of large-scale greening too high for a city grappling with poverty and corruption. Thus, legal and financial systems must become more robust before greening can reap the benefits Wilson details.
At HSBC, I undertook work experience in Global Trade, analysing data on the environmental impact of supply chains. This deepened my understanding of sustainable business activity and improved my data literacy skills. Analysing ESG reports, I was able to assess and recommend opportunities for HSBC to finance sustainable projects. This experience revealed the interdependence of economics and the environment, a relationship at the core of Geography and Economics.

feedback_items.weak_passage: sustaining social division
feedback_items.your_feedback: Maybe 'sustaining' is not the best word there - it's usually used in more of a positive context. But this is really picking hairs.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Consider a word like 'perpetuating' or 'reinforcing' instead of 'sustaining'.

feedback_items.your_feedback: Overall, there's really nothing I can give you to improve this that wouldn't make it look less authentic and therefore actually be a negative. I think you've developed out your ideas really well. All the topics you've chosen are very well thought out, very interesting. You clearly have done the research, done the work. You clearly enjoy and understand the subjects really well. It reads really well. It's definitely the best one I've read this year by quite a distance.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Move on to mock interview preparation and interview preparation - if you don't get an interview, I would be absolutely shocked. Focus on what you're doing to prepare for August-November: reading in advance of A2/university, other preparation work.
feedback_items.strong_passage: A UNIQ Summer School lecture introduced me to Ghanaian farming tenancy contracts. I was particularly interested in the 'abunu' system (where landlord and farmer share land and produce equally). Realising the potential for power asymmetry between landlord and farmer, I wanted to understand their relationship further. To this end, I read an article on tenurial relations in rural Ghana. Its argument that abunu inhibits land control and equality for farmers was valid. However, by ignoring the economic rationale for choosing the contracts, it failed to address why these arrangements persist. I resolved this by modelling hypothetical cost and revenue functions to compare outcomes in abunu and a fixed rent system. Abunu, though less profitable, mitigated the financial risk of failed harvests and labour shortages present in fixed rent agreements. This risk-averse response showed me how uncertainty influences choice, a theme I discussed in my commended entry to the Gerald O'Connell Essay Prize.
feedback_items.why_strong: This demonstrates exceptional critical thinking: identifies a gap in existing research, conducts independent analysis using economic modeling, draws sophisticated conclusions about risk and decision-making, and connects to broader themes. Shows genuine intellectual curiosity and research capability.

feedback_items.your_feedback: Your stats are exceptional - really, no notes on that. You must have worked so hard. You've done everything perfectly so far.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Consider requesting a mock interview as the next step in preparation. Focus on articulating your research and ideas verbally.
feedback_items.strong_passage: Caldeira's 'City of Walls' exposed me to how urban geography can reveal power imbalances embedded into cities... This challenged me to see space not as neutral, but a device for socio-economic and political control. A Guardian article on Brazilian social housing highlighted the ineffective policy response of the government. I mostly agreed with the critique that housing was distant from economic activity and construction firms prioritised profitable margins over quality. Yet, the article ignored the benefits of state-backed mortgage and credit provision to São Paulo's poorest families, enabling property ownership. This tension showed me how policy can promote economic inclusion and entrench inequality.
feedback_items.why_strong: Demonstrates sophisticated understanding of urban geography, critically evaluates sources (agreeing with some points while identifying gaps), and recognizes policy tensions and trade-offs. Shows nuanced thinking about complex social issues.

feedback_items.your_feedback: I don't want to give you any notes on the personal statement. Just let me know what you're working on at the moment, and we'll see what we can do - maybe arrange something in the next couple of weeks where we check in and give you pointers, or set you up with somebody studying land economy for tips. But honestly, you don't need it. You're doing really, really well.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Continue with interview preparation. Consider connecting with current Land Economy students for insights.
feedback_items.strong_passage: Reading Ben Wilson's 'Urban Jungle' made me question nature's place in the contemporary city. I explored his central argument, that rewilding cities reflects our innate affinity to nature, further through a research project into biophilic design in Singapore. My research, which I entered to the St John's College Poster Competition, involved analysing data from health journal articles to understand the effects of natural spaces like Gardens by the Bay on mental health. In finding reductions in depression and anxiety risk, the benefits of greening were clear. Yet, there were also limitations. Extensive capital investment and coordination are needed to promote urban greening, making me question its feasibility in all urban contexts. These limitations became clearer in considering Lagos. I found the opportunity cost of large-scale greening too high for a city grappling with poverty and corruption.
feedback_items.why_strong: Takes an idea from reading, extends it through independent research with data analysis, recognizes both benefits and limitations, and applies critical thinking about feasibility in different contexts (Singapore vs Lagos). Shows research skills and nuanced understanding of trade-offs.

subject: Economics and Management
statement_full_text:
Why do you want to study this course or subject?
Commuting between home and school takes me from cracked sidewalks and corner shops to tree-lined streets and luxury houses. This exposure to inequality introduced economics and management as tools to understand the issues that individuals, firms, and governments hesitate to confront. My experiences in studying them reinforces my commitment to these subjects.
How have your qualifications and studies helped you to prepare for this course or subject?
"Utopia for Realists" by Rutger Bregman confronts this inequality by exploring how a focus on capital has restricted labour markets. He argues that government policy should rebalance this dynamic. However, I question his thesis as the costs of not utilising capital, from lower performance to lower wages can further limit labour, exacerbating inequality. Capital-driven firms have historically driven innovation, and I believe government intervention might limit this progress. Although this revealed inequality as a link between firm and government behaviour, I was unconvinced that I discovered the root forces that sustain inequality in its various forms around the world.
"The Winner-Take-All Society" argues that marginal advantages lead to disproportionate rewards, concentrating wealth and income among a few people. I agree as this deepened my belief that society has a flawed association of wealth and status with capability. My independent research investigation on if the Matthew Effect occurs in firms' job shortlisting assessed how major success can depend on minor conditions beyond your control. What fascinated me was how my subjects rewarded the privileged over equally capable candidates from disadvantaged backgrounds, echoing Rivera and Tilcsik's report on socioeconomic markers. I believe this produces a suboptimal labour market as talent is systematically overlooked and underutilised, reflecting the environments many people work in. Naturally, my investigation questioned the responsibility firms bear in addressing inequality.
In the Minds Underground essay competition, I mentioned a Universal Basic Income could be funded by corporate taxes on economic assets like data. I now contend this, as it inhibits digital investment and disincentivises market entry as data's role in innovation and competition expands. This introduced economics as a study that unpacks the nuanced interactions among economic agents, and prepares me to explore their connection more through ways like strategic deployment.
A class on the impacts of US' tariffs introduced me to international competition. In an essay, I concluded that protectionism reduces the appeal of international trade, prompting nations to rely on inefficient domestic production. Founding my co-podcast ("Insight to Econ" on Spotify) allowed me to study this further by discussing how managerial economics can help recognise how firms adapt to tariffs. It was insightful to learn that in these conditions, managers often prioritise survival over profit, demonstrated by Apple diversifying their supply chain beyond China to reduce recent tariff impacts. Orally expressing these ideas prepared me to excel to the Finals Day in the Oxford Schools Debating competition. I enjoyed arguing that companies should get management to periodically work entry level jobs, challenging the hierarchical structure in many firms. However, I learned that this depends on if their current organisational structure leans towards a mechanistic or organic model.
What else have you done to prepare outside of education, and why are these experiences useful?
Speaking with NatWest's operations team revealed how the UK challenges have scarred the bank. Showing how they analyse problems helped me to see how AI models enhance solutions. My EPQ argued that AI could replace human work, but I was challenged after learning from Coutts who use LLMs in wealth management services. Both work experiences taught me that the cost of AI technology often exceeds labour, contrary to my original belief. Economics and management are not just about what can happen, but what actually does - in the practical space where theory meets the reality I am eager to study further.

feedback_items.weak_passage: Commuting between home and school takes me from cracked sidewalks and corner shops to tree-lined streets and luxury houses.
feedback_items.your_feedback: This is not particularly interesting or insightful. It's a sign of inequality but quite an underdeveloped understanding because inequality is multidimensional - it isn't just cracked roads and houses. All cities are like that (London is a fantastic example). I think you can come up with something better, or just go straight into a book.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Either develop this with a more sophisticated understanding of multidimensional inequality, or remove it and start directly with 'Utopia for Realists'.

feedback_items.weak_passage: "Utopia for Realists" by Rutger Bregman confronts this inequality by exploring how a focus on capital has restricted labour markets. He argues that government policy should rebalance this dynamic.
feedback_items.your_feedback: You don't explain well enough what this guy's thesis is. What is the focus on capital? What do you mean by that? How has it restricted labour markets? To what extent? Is there anything else mentioned? Is that your opinion that government policy should rebalance, or is it his? To correct this market failure, is government intervention the only way? In which type of economy? Not everybody has the same labour markets - there are different frictions and structural issues. There's a lot missing.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Clearly explain: what 'focus on capital' means specifically, how it restricts labour markets (with examples), and whether this applies universally or to specific contexts. Distinguish between the author's argument and your response.

feedback_items.weak_passage: the costs of not utilising capital, from lower performance to lower wages can further limit labour, exacerbating inequality
feedback_items.your_feedback: What do you mean by 'costs of not utilising capital'? From lower performance to lower wages - limiting labour how? Exacerbating inequality how? These are buzzwords but not clearly explained. It's much better to give concrete examples like discussing high minimum wages in the UK making labour markets less flexible, comparing gig economy in UK vs US, how Uber works differently. Walk through in normal language how things actually work rather than summarising big ideas in very short spaces.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Replace abstract language with specific examples: name a country, a policy, a specific labor market effect, and concrete outcomes. Show the mechanism, don't just assert it.

feedback_items.weak_passage: "The Winner-Take-All Society" argues that marginal advantages lead to disproportionate rewards
feedback_items.your_feedback: This seems to come from nowhere. It doesn't naturally follow from the previous discussion. The flow isn't 'this and then this and then this' - the connection between topics is unclear.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Add a connecting sentence that explains why you're moving from capital/labour discussion to winner-take-all dynamics.

feedback_items.weak_passage: My independent research investigation on if the Matthew Effect occurs in firms' job shortlisting assessed how major success can depend on minor conditions beyond your control.
feedback_items.your_feedback: What are the minor conditions? I don't know. What major success? I don't know. What fascinated you was how subjects rewarded privileged over capable candidates - why? You don't explain why this is happening. I think you're assuming we're going to read into this and realize some advantage (maybe wealth and status), but it's so underexplained.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Specify: what 'minor conditions' you studied (family wealth? educational background? zip code?), what 'major success' means (job offers? salary?), and the mechanism by which privilege translates to advantage in shortlisting.

feedback_items.weak_passage: This introduced economics as a study that unpacks the nuanced interactions among economic agents, and prepares me to explore their connection more through ways like strategic deployment.
feedback_items.your_feedback: I don't like this definition of economics at all. You don't need to get a definition of economics. It's too broad to put into one sentence like this. Just discussing various ideas in economics is going to be stronger because it will show you understand the various parts of it.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Remove this definition. Let your discussion of specific economic ideas throughout the statement demonstrate your understanding of the discipline.

feedback_items.weak_passage: I concluded that protectionism reduces the appeal of international trade, prompting nations to rely on inefficient domestic production.
feedback_items.your_feedback: That's not really a conclusion because that's just a fact. The whole point of protectionism is that it reduces trade. It's like saying 2 equals 2.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Instead of stating the obvious definition, present a non-obvious insight or analysis about protectionism - its effectiveness, unintended consequences, or comparative outcomes.

feedback_items.weak_passage: managers often prioritise survival over profit, demonstrated by Apple diversifying their supply chain beyond China to reduce recent tariff impacts
feedback_items.your_feedback: Surely diversifying supply chain to reduce tariff impact IS looking at bottom line profit. What is the difference between survival and profit for you? This distinction isn't clear.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Clarify what you mean by 'survival over profit' - perhaps short-term vs long-term thinking, or accepting lower margins for supply security. Make the distinction meaningful and clear.

feedback_items.weak_passage: I enjoyed arguing that companies should get management to periodically work entry level jobs, challenging the hierarchical structure in many firms.
feedback_items.your_feedback: You don't explain why this challenges hierarchy or what the point is. How does that affect firm efficiency? Is there something about company culture? What about organizational structure - mechanistic vs organic models?
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Explain the rationale: does this improve information flow? Reduce principal-agent problems? Build empathy? And why does the mechanistic/organic structure matter for this policy?

feedback_items.your_feedback: Because this is my subject, I'm being meaner than usual. You are clearly smart - this is not about you. You've gotten in your head about how to write at a higher and higher level, which makes sentences very confusing. Some ideas are half-developed, some are vague, some aren't. I was going to walk through everything but I think you need to restart.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Start fresh with simple bullet points: This is the point I want to make. This is the source. This is the theory I understood. This is what it connects to in real life or another paper. Build 3 strong bullet-pointed paragraphs, then connect them with simple sentences, THEN think about complex structures. The theories and ideas are good and high-level - you just need to develop them properly.

feedback_items.your_feedback: This is sufficient for sure - the essay competitions, ideas are high-level and complex. But if you have time, fix these points. Remove definitions. If you bring in a thesis, make it really clearly explained. Fully develop things - don't be vague about effects and minor conditions. If you mention something, explain what they are in specific terms. Don't assume knowledge, don't assume I'll agree, don't point out obvious things.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Key fixes: 1) Remove or improve the opening. 2) Clearly explain each book's thesis before critiquing it. 3) Add specific examples throughout (countries, policies, firms, outcomes). 4) Explain mechanisms, don't just assert effects. 5) Remove obvious conclusions. 6) Develop the Matthew Effect research with specifics. 7) Remove the economics definition. 8) Clarify survival vs profit distinction.
